awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A National Assessment of Victimization Risk and Crime Reporting
awd_abstract_narration:
The U.S. crime statistics system historically has not incorporated information about citizenship status, and thus there is little scientific evidence that can inform whether immigrants are more or less likely than native-born Americans to be criminally victimized. Such an information deficit also means we do not know whether immigrants are more or less likely than natives to report crimes to the police.  This project capitalizes on a recent redesign of the U.S. National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS), which adds information about respondents' citizenship status, to offer the first large-scale comparison of victimization risk and crime reporting among U.S. native-born citizens, naturalized citizens, and non-citizens.  The results of the project will reveal how citizenship status shapes personal exposure to crime and decisions about whether to report crimes to the police.  Additionally, the project will examine whether these patterns vary among individuals from different racial and ethnic groups and among those who reside in communities with divergent approaches to immigration policy and law enforcement.  The project will benefit policy-makers at all governmental levels by providing key information regarding patterns of crime victimization and crime reporting among U.S. residents.  Findings will also inform police leadership regarding these patterns, thus contributing to U.S. safety and security.

The project has three primary objectives: (1) to assess the quality of the new self-reported citizenship data in the NCVS for purposes of developing adjustments (if needed) for any observed nonresponse bias; (2) to examine the effect of citizenship status on victimization risk and how it may be conditioned by individual- and community-level factors; and (3) to examine the effect of citizenship status on crime reporting to the police and how it may be conditioned by individual- and community-level conditions.  The project will integrate nationally representative individual-level data on victimization and crime reporting from the redesigned 2016-2020 National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS) and community-level data from the American Community Survey (ACS) and a variety of other sources including reports of state immigration legislation, LexisNexis, and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) documents.   Multivariate logistic regression models will be estimated to achieve project objectives.  The results will yield new evidence about the safety and well-being of native-born citizens and foreign-born persons in the context of rapidly changing economic, demographic, and political conditions in the US.  The project will which enhance knowledge about the quality of survey-derived measures of citizenship and will provide the first ever assessment at the national level of whether immigrant status is associated with victimization risk and decisions to notify the police about crime incidents. These findings will inform sociological theories regarding crime, immigration and citizenship status, as well as criminological theories related to crime victimization and mobilization of the law, with implications for additional literatures in political science and survey methodology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project has yielded significant outcomes related both to intellectual contributions and broader impacts.

Intellectual Merit

The project?s findings reveal new knowledge about the measurement of citizenship in a large-scale victimization survey and about the role of indicators of immigrant status in shaping victimization risk and crime reporting decisions.  These new insights make an important contribution to social science knowledge in three ways:

1. A published paper in the leading journal on crime and justice (Xie and Baumer, 2021, Criminology) documented, for the first time, that respondents to the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS) who provided non-valid responses to the citizenship item had other demographic, socioeconomic, and household attributes that closely paralleled the observed characteristics of unauthorized immigrants.

Xie, Min and Baumer, Eric P. (2021). Immigrant status, citizenship, and victimization risk in the United States: New findings from the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS).  Criminology, 59(4), 610-644. https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/1745-9125.12278

2. A published paper in the leading journal on crime and justice (Xie and Baumer, 2021, Criminology) documented, for the first time, that after controlling for other factors, there is a continuum of victimization risk on which naturalized citizens and known noncitizens are placed on the one end of the continuum with a lower risk of victimization, whereas U.S.-born citizens and the ambiguous citizenship status respondents are on the other end of the continuum with a higher risk of victimization.

Xie, Min and Baumer, Eric P. (2021). Immigrant status, citizenship, and victimization risk in the United States: New findings from the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS).  Criminology, 59(4), 610-644. https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/1745-9125.12278

3. The project findings document, for the first time, the importance of considering key markers of immigrant status -- citizenship status and indicators of limited English language proficiency -- in studies of crime reporting.  The results indicate that the commonly assumed inverse association between immigrant status and crime reporting may be exaggerated. These findings are currently being prepared for publication.

Broader Impacts

The project yielded broader impacts for society, education, and research infrastructure.

1. Broader impacts for society. The project yielded new insights about how markers of immigrant status shape personal exposure to crime and decisions about whether to report crimes to the police, which contribute to the public dialogue about immigration. 

2. Broader impacts for education and mentorship. The project had a positive impact on educational experiences by (a) facilitating the integration of project materials into an undergraduate course at Penn State University, and (b) providing the centerpiece to the graduate training and mentoring of students at Penn State University and the University of Maryland.

3. Broader impacts for research infrastructure. The project served as a platform from which three widely attended virtual public webinars that featured the main data source used in the research -- the National Crime Victimization Survey -- and leading scholars of victimization and crime reporting. These webinars introduced the NCVS to a large pool of potential new data users, highlighted some of the scientific questions that can be addressed with the data, and reviewed some of the key issues in the appropriate use of the data. This should have positive benefits for research infrastructure.
